=You are part of the business development team at Irenictech which is an AI consultancy. 

When a new leads book a consultation with Irenictech, your team researches the leads and provides the research + extracted insights to the consultants so they can read it prior to the consult. 

Your job is to create the following sections from the research:

- Personal Profile: The personal profile is a one paragraph summary of the person (lead) extracted from researching their LinkedIn profile.
- Interests: In this section you must identify a few of the leads interests from their most recent LinkedIn posts + their LinkedIn profile. 
- Unique Facts: In this section you must extract at least 2 unique facts about the lead that tells them you've really put time to research who they are. These facts should be things that are unique to the lead and out of the ordinary.
- Company Profile: The company profile is a one paragraph summary of the company the person represents, extracted from researching their company LinkedIn profile and available information on the web. 

Your output must be in HTML, following this format: 

Person Profile (Heading 2)
[Details]

Company Profile (Heading 2)
[Details]

Interests (Heading 2)
[List of interests in dot point format]

Unique Facts (Heading 2)
[List of unique facts in dot point format]


- Don't wrap the output in ```html``` since the output will go into the middle of another HTML document. Just make sure its in HTML language.

Create this output for the following research: 

LinkedIn Profile Research (in JSON format): 
{{ $('Scrape Profiles + Posts - Relevance AI').item.json.linkedin_profile_details_data.about }}

Most Recent LinkedIn Posts: 
{{ $('Scrape Profiles + Posts - Relevance AI').item.json.linkedin_data }}

Web Research: 
{{ $('Message a model').item.json.message.content }}

=You are part of the business development team at Irenictech which is an AI consultancy. 

When new leads book a consultation with Irenictech, your team researches the leads and provides the research + extracted insights to the consultants so they can read it prior the consult. 

As an ice breaker for each call, [YOUR-NAME], which is Irenictech's AI consultant likes to point to a similarity between himself and the lead. This way the lead feels more comfortable talking to [YOUR-NAME] as a friend, rather than a stranger. 

To find these similarities you must compare [YOUR-NAME]'s LinkedIn profile to the leads LinkedIn profile. Look for any similarities you can find, including but not limited to education, experience, location, interests and so on. 

You might also not find any similarities. In this case then output No Similarities Found in the details section of your output. 

Your output must be in the following HTML format: 

Similarities (heading 2)
[Details in dot points with one similarity on each dot point]

- Don't wrap the output in ```html``` since the output will go into the middle of another HTML document.

The Leads LinkedIn Profile: 
{{ $('Scrape Profiles + Posts - Relevance AI').item.json.linkedin_profile_details_data.about }}

[YOUR-NAME]'s LinkedIn Profile: 
[INPUT YOUR DETAILS HERE - YOU CAN SCRAPE YOUR PROFILE USING THIS WORKFLOW AND HARDCODE THE INFO HERE]

=You are part of the business development team at Irenictech. Irenictech is an AI Automation agency that provides the following services: 

- AI Consulting: Irenictech provides consultations to businesses looking to implement AI. 
- Process Automation: Kamexa automates processes that are repetitive, time consuming, high volume or error prone. These repetitive proccesses are automated with traditional rule based automations. 
- AI SaaS Development: For businesses that can automate their entire service, Irenictech creates a SaaS platform so that they can provide their services over the cloud in a one to many fashion. 
- AI Agent Development: Irenictech develops custom AI agents that can handle less repetitive tasks autonomously. Considering the current capabilities of AI agents, the tasks that they can complete have to be simple in scope. 

Irenictech's AI consultants are the first point of contact for a new lead. So when a new lead is interested in AI Automation solutions, they book a free call with Irenictech's AI consultants. The consultants are then responsible for exploring the highest ROI opportunities for automation.

Once a call is booked, your team does in depth research on the lead so that the consultants can read through it in preparation for the consultation. 

As part of the business development team you are provided with the following research: 

- LinkedIn Profile: This is the result of scraping the leads LinkedIn profile. This will give you the leads bio, experiences, education and company description.
- LinkedIn Posts: This gives you the leads LinkedIn posts over the past 30 days. 
- Company Google Search: This gives you the research found from searching the leads company on Google and their website. 
- Reviews: This gives you the most recent bad reviews the leads company received on TrustPilot. 

Your job is to analyse the research and extract following information: 

- Pain Points: By looking through the companies negative reviews and also considering their line of business and the leads position in the company, you must identify the biggest pain points the leads company could be facing. 
- Solutions to Pain Points: In this section you must come up with solutions Kamexa can offer to solve each of the pain points completely. 
- Highest ROI Automation Opportunities: Considering the info you have about the lead and his company, you must come up with the 5 highest ROI automation opportunities that Kamexa can offer them. These automations have to be realisitic, yet extremely high ROI. Sort them in order of best opportunity at the top of the list.  

The insights you extract must be in HTML format as they will be going in the middle of a HTML document. 

Please use the following output format: 

Opportunities (Heading 1)

Pain Points and Solutions: (Heading 2)
[Table with 3 columns: 
1. Pain Point: Explains the pain point theyre facing. 
2. Evidence: Explains why we think this is the case. 
3. Solution: Explains the solution to the pain point by Kamexa.
Each row is a new pain point.]

Automation Opportunities: (Heading 2)
[5 Highest ROI automation opportunities for the leads company sorted with the best solution at the top. This must be in dotpoint format:
- Opportunity#1 Name: Details
- Opportunity#2 Name: Details
...

- Don't wrap the output in ```html``` since the output will go into the middle of another HTML document.

Someone just booked a call. Here's the research your team found. Create the output as per the above requirements: 


LinkedIn Profile Scraped Summary in HTML format: 
{{ $('Person + Company Profile').item.json.message.content }}

Web Research Results for Leads Company:
{{ $('Message a model').item.json.message.content }}

poster.headline: ðŸ“ˆ Fractional Ops + Customer Journey | Startup Consultant | Tech Equity

linkedin_data.text:
Because AI integration in human life is moving at lightning speed, I knew I had to be in the room for The AI Collective: The Future of Work, to hear directly from leaders and practitioners about what theyâ€™re building, hiring for, and how AI is reshaping work as we know it.

Co-host Brennan M. Woodruff, Director of Strategic Partnerships at mHUB , reminded us of the need to understand the regulatory hurdles that have the ability to impact progress. (See BIPA). Alongside co-host Matthew Louis, thank you both for fostering a thoughtful space grounded in community, learning, and presence.

A few insights:

Elizabeth Barisik from Visier on agentic AI as a baseline for business and enterprise SaaS development â€” where data + context = the new moat. She emphasized the rapid growth of AI use behind the scenes, transforming ideas into tangible assets, way faster than we think.

Nickhil Tekwani- leading in product and Gen AI at McDonalds, shared how AI can drive customer feel-good moments through latency unlocks and improved experience connectivity.

Nate Carson shared insights on Uberâ€™s AI adoption through the future of â€œhumanâ€ work in enhancing AI models.

Chris Andersonâ€™s story was truly inspiring. I love how he and his wife brought their children along their science and technology journey. What started with Lego kits contributed to an AI-powered global defense system! Â He also invited us to demo his new product -Â Ai.rplane

Makunde G. - building an amazing career and shared his journey to Google. He recommendedÂ book Algorithms of Oppression â€” a powerful reminder that algorithms can marginalize as easily as they can innovate. Makunde emphasizes community as the foundation for innovation for all.

Michelangelo D'Agostino (Grainger) noted the need for net-new assets vs. retrofitting existing systems. He shared Graingerâ€™s rich Chicago history and how it has led in innovation over the past nearly 100 years.

Cait Moran emphasized the humanâ€™s role in the future of AI, focused on emotionally intelligent design for autonomous digital teams. â€œDonâ€™t teach tools. Teach decision-making.â€

But my absolute favorite moment?
ðŸ§  Following the event, a deep, perspective-shifting conversation with Shawn HE YUXUN on quantum AI and the future of human utility when our â€œfirst-person viewâ€ begins to orbit around AI.

And the icing on the cake? I got to share the experience with my wonderful sister Kymberley R. â¤ï¸

linkedin_data.text:
Nope, I'm not an agentic AI expert, but my understanding is growing every day! 

Great session today from the Agentic AI Conference hosted by Data Science Dojo. "Architecting Retrieval Systems for Agentic AI" brought forward a conversation where even a novice like me can follow along - with a couple of term searches :-)

Several takeaways about the future of agent networks:

MCP = Model Context Protocol. It connects AI models, like large language models (LLMs), to various external data sources and tools. Developed by Anthropic.
> MCP servers act like modular, authenticated data sources.
> MCP terminals can index a group of MCP servers, which can be chained together.
> Agents communicate across the created network using permissioned protocols.
> MCPs reduce siloing by enabling shared memory and interoperability.
> Real-world use cases: ETL automation, secure data retrieval, autonomous workflows.
> Integration with MCP is growing; Google announced adoption last month. This means that standardization is likely coming.

Deep expertise panel: Bob van Luijt, Raja Iqbal, Jerry Liu, Tallat M. Shafaat, Emil Eifrem

Much appreciation to 1871 for another impactful signature event! ScaleUp 2025 offered growth-stage founders the insights, tools, connections, and discussions needed to move into the next phase of maturity for greater scale. Special thanks to BMO Tower for hosting us in their beautiful space.

For those who missed it or are curious about the types of discussions held (and my quick take):

Keynote with 1871 CEO Betsy Ziegler and Alex Jones, CEO & Co-Founder Hallow.
Alex shared the challenges of scaling the #1 Christian meditation and prayer app while keeping his spiritual focus strong as a mechanism to push through growing pains.

Scaling the Future of Smart Farming with Oishii.
This is seriously cool food tech. Oishiiâ€™s â€œbeautiful tasteâ€ comes from perfect strawberries grown in a pesticide-free, climate-controlled, AI-enabled smart farming system. I can confirm they taste amazing :-)

Panel: Innovating Without Breaking the Bank, led by Stuart Bernstein.
In this economic landscape, this was the news founders need. Topics included enabling innovation, fostering a culture of problem-solving, and strategies for experimenting and iterating, all while staying aligned with growth plans.

Panel: The Future of Work & Investment, led by Angi Milano.
Lean scaling, organizational effectiveness, acceleration with AI as table stakes, the pros and cons of having a co-founder, and the evolution of investing through the VC lens.

Fireside chat with Betsy Z. and Wallace Harris, Jr., President at BMO Harris Investment Services.
The focus here was on building and investing in community as a mechanism for business growth and developmentâ€”a powerful reminder that community-driven growth is real. Wallace also spoke on moving past the 'no' to find workable solutions.

The 1871 team truly delivers excellence at every single event. Their behind-the-scenes efforts are what make these experiences not just successful, but impactful. Major kudos to the team!

Grateful for the community weâ€™re building. I got to catch up with Chrystal Price and Daniel Hernandez, and made new connections with Alex Olson and Mellini Monique.

linkedin_data.text:
My father is an entrepreneur. Heâ€™s 75 years old. One of my first memories of his designs is a glow in the dark gym shoe sent to Nike in the early 80s. He never heard back.

Another one of his many memorable ideas was â€œBrother Aidsâ€ in the late 80s, to introduce adhesive bandages for brown-skinned people.

My mother was an entrepreneur. She sold Queenâ€™s Way clothing, Avon, Tupperware, Brown & Bigelow. I recall attending different home events.

In the late 80s they opened a t-shirt shop, selling a variety of heat-pressed and custom designs, plus my father was delivering custom spray painting designs. The business thrived. My sister worked there. My father began screen printing in the evenings, and they built to securing 1000+ item orders. I remember a lot of t-shirt folding!

My father later opened a cleaning business serving other businesses, employing family and friends.

My father worked full time as an electrician from 19 years old until retirement. He continued as a practicing electrician until his late 60s, including serving for several years as an electrician instructor.

My mother worked full time as a mental health physicianâ€™s assistant for many years. I would go to work with her sometimes, filing and calling the patients back to the doctor. Later she transitioned full time into the t-shirt business.

So, you can say that I was exposed early to building things from ideas as well as building dreams 'on the side'. 

Thatâ€™s why I favor startups, because I love the visionaries and doers who create tangible value at scale.

Cheers to those who have the nerve to build their dreams.

P.S. My father is finalizing a patent for a new product. Iâ€™ll be sure to share when heâ€™s ready.Â â™¥ï¸

The Catch-22. The Gift and the Curse. The Rock and a Hard Place.

You really donâ€™t want your customers describing your B2B SaaS startup like this.

But it happens when... 
} The product is sticky but clunky.
} When switching feels painful, but staying isnâ€™t delivering value.
} When teams are â€œmanaging through it,â€ but not seeing outcomes.

Thatâ€™s not loyalty. Thatâ€™s resignation. And itâ€™s a churn risk waiting to materialize.

ðŸš« You donâ€™t want to be â€œtoo embedded to leaveâ€
âœ… You want to be â€œtoo valuable to loseâ€

So how do you avoid becoming the necessary evil in someoneâ€™s tech stack?

1ï¸âƒ£ Obsess over Time-to-Value (TTV)
2ï¸âƒ£ Align Product, Sales, and CS around customer outcomes
3ï¸âƒ£ Ask hard questions early: â€œWould you buy this again today?â€

Customer relationships built on perceived pain are brittle.

Value-first relationships are built to grow.

Where does your product sit today? Is it a necessary evil or essential solution?

poster.headline: ðŸ“ˆ Fractional Ops + Customer Journey | Startup Consultant | Tech Equity

linkedin_data.text:
Hereâ€™s the hard truth: growth doesnâ€™t happen until your product seamlessly solves real pain points for your ideal customers.

If thatâ€™s not happening yet, here are a few usual suspects:

(1) You built before deeply understanding your ICP. Always a no-no to build before the customer need can be articulated.

(2) You havenâ€™t talked to enough customers who match your ICP. Generic conversations with people willing to talk to you don't count.

(3) Your product solves only part of the problem. Perhaps itâ€™s too slow, buggy, or unclear. 

This is the moment to take a breath. Then take a step back.

You canâ€™t fake traction. But you can gain it with clarity.

Start by setting one simple goal:
>> Talk to 15 customers within your ICP within the next week.

Ask better questions. Listen for patterns. Revisit your assumptions.
>> Then: research, reflect, refine.

What might you learn, about your customers or your product, if you truly listened with nothing to prove? ðŸ¤”
__
#B2BSaaS #SaaSGrowth #NRR #Retention #StartupOperations #CustomerExperience #Fractional #Product

linkedin_data.text:
You just had to be there.

1871â€™s final signature event, "Emerging Tech Innovation Summit" at the Merchandise Mart, was a bold look ahead. For two days, the space was alive with energy from AI and Web3 leaders, investors, and builders shaping the next wave of innovation. I chose the AI track â€” focused on how industries are navigating adoption at scale and where real impact lies.

There was so much to take in, but hereâ€™s a glimpse of what stuck with me:

Keith Toney, EVP, Discover: Talked candidly about AIâ€™s â€œchange ceilingâ€ â€” where layers of data access, organizational fear, and governance challenges can stall innovation. You have to recognize AI fear as real. Label it. Talk about it. Build the right sponsorship. And, only build things you can't buy.

Matt Renner, who leads cybersecurity at Antares Capital, offered a powerful framework for thinking about effective AI implementation. He emphasized that true scale comes from repeatability â€” itâ€™s not enough to have one-off wins; success hinges on consistent execution across use cases. He underscored the need for clear leadership alignment, warning that without top-down clarity, AI efforts often stall.

"AI in Academia - Transforming the Classroom and Beyond"
Xiaochen Z., CEO, Fintech4Good: Co-hosted the day and led the panel that challenged us to think globally â€” policy, education, and ethics must shape responsible AI.
< Aravinda Garimella, Professor, Gies
 I really enjoyed Aravinda's commentary and perspective on building the next generation of AI contributors and leaders. She's super committed to ensuring both tacit and explicit student knowledge. Aravinda raised and discussed a critical point: academia must evolve both ethically and technically to lead in the AI era. 
< David Zaretsky, PhD, Professor, Pritzker School of Law
Amongst many areas of expertise, David teaches an amazing course on the evolution of AI and its ethical and legal considerations to law students at Northwestern - literally building the course in real-time to ensure the latest insights and updates are interwoven into student learning and understanding. I'd love to be invited to observe a class!

"Web3 & AI - A Real Conversation About Energy & Data cCenters"
< Amber Orr, Director of Engineering & Energy Services
 Through her breadth of industry knowledge, she so casually educated us about 'power factor', edge compute and power delivery. Amber reminded us that energy and infrastructure arenâ€™t side notes but are truly at center stage in scalable AI. You gained a fan.

Huge congrats to the AI startup pitch finalists:
DeepNeed, Levee, MEGI Health, nutrÄd, Oraczen â€” bold ideas, sharp execution! I'm rooting for you all.

I'm always grateful for new conversations, so thanks to Noma S., Rob Wellen, MSIM, and Kyree Blount â€” letâ€™s keep building.

As always, thank you Betsy Ziegler and the incredible 1871 team for a fitting finale at the Mart â€” and the spark for whatâ€™s next.

You can't grow community without showing up. Letâ€™s build!

poster.headline: ðŸ“ˆ Fractional Ops + Customer Journey | Startup Consultant | Tech Equity

linkedin_data.text:
Is your B2B SaaS startup ready for scale? Maybe.

Here are 5 signals that prove it isnâ€™t (and what to do ASAP):

1. No clear #ICP (Ideal Customer Profile).
 â†’ Fix it: Segment current users, identify your most successful customers, and build your messaging and roadmap around them.

2. #Growth is driven solely by new logos.
 â†’ Fix it: Build expansion paths into the product experience and train teams to spot growth triggers early.

3. Customers arenâ€™t reaching 'true' #activation.
 â†’ Fix it: Map the customer journey, define Time-to-Value (TTV), and simplify onboarding before acquiring more users.

4. Sales, Customer Success, and Product are misaligned.
 â†’ Fix it: Create shared success metrics across functions and establish regular cross-functional syncs.

5. Churn is treated as a customer support problem.
 â†’ Fix it: Build a proactive retention systemâ€”health scoring, feedback loops, and early renewal playbooks.

Scaling a SaaS company isnâ€™t easy, but it is doable.
The path forward is about growing smart. This means alignment across teams, clear operational strategy, and relentless focus on delivering measurable value.

Take some time to reflect. Are you building the set of systems to make your company sustainable?
--

linkedin_data.text:
I spend most of my time trying to operate in a balance of two states: (1) being objective and agnostic, moved only by evidence and data, and (2) relying on discernment, intuition, and energy sensing. The goal? To step away from judgment and make choices anchored in â€œWhat is the best decision for this moment?â€

This week, I caught up with a former customer I havenâ€™t worked with in years. To me, one of the best professional compliments is staying connected with someone as a friend long after the work has ended. Our collaboration was always about more than the contract, the upgrade, the support issue, or the delayed product delivery. 

At its core, it came down to transparency, honesty, owning mistakes, a sense of urgency, and a commitment to finding solutions. The same things we value in great people, not just great workers.

I recently read a book that described life as â€œone big referral.â€ It struck me as profoundly true, especially when paired with the idea that â€œpeople will never forget how you made them feel.â€ Weâ€™re sometimes led to believe that the smile, the laugh, the joke, the pleasantries > the humanness < arenâ€™t necessary for success. But my experience has shown me otherwise.

Do such good work, in such a great way, that people will carry your name into rooms youâ€™ve never entered. That theyâ€™ll think of you, not just for what you delivered, but for how you showed up. That long after the emails, meetings, and transactions fade, what remains is the trust, the connection, and the impact.

Because at the end of the day, the best work is both about what you do AND who you are while doing it.

Itâ€™s been a minute since Iâ€™ve shared an update, but Iâ€™m hopping back on the train because this is still a very exciting time for Tenacity AI.

We're focused on connecting high-caliber college students to paid, project-based work at startups. I thought it would be super straightforward and easy, but one of the biggest lessons I'm learning is that quality experience truly mattersâ€”for both students and startups.

For students, they need an opportunity where they can actually land the job, do well, earn money, and make real connections that move their careers forward. So, my responsibility is to deliver an experience where they're connecting to exciting opportunities and feel supported with the right tools and resources to be successful on every project. 

For startups, they need high-quality work, minimal friction, and tangible results.  This means we have to be rigorous in vetting student freelancers, making sure they're sharp, adaptable, and can handle both direction and ambiguity. Founders don't have time for hand-holdingâ€”they need work that's efficient and impactful. 

It's a balancing act for sure, but if we get it right, the experience on both sides will be game-changing.

So, if you know top-tier college Juniors or Seniors who would thrive in a startup gig, send them our way. They can apply using the link.

Shoutout to Lake Forest College, Ball State University, and Northwestern Universityâ€”weâ€™re already working with some of your best marketing and tech students.

linkedin_data.text:
Most retention playbooks fail because they treat churn as a Customer Success problem.

After founding and scaling customer operations for two SaaS startups that successfully exited, I learned that when customers quit a company it isnâ€™t just about how well a customer success team supports users; itâ€™s about the entire customer journey.

If retention is slipping, the issue is rarely isolated to CS. The big picture tells a different story.

At first, I focused on the customer-facing team aligning structures, goals, and processes. But over time, one truth became impossible to ignore:

Some of the biggest retention opportunities/challenges start long before CS has a chance to intervene.

Â >> Sales sets the promise.
Â >> Product delivers the promise.
Â >> Customer Success activates the customer and ensures they realize the value.

When these three teams arenâ€™t in sync, even the best CS strategy wonâ€™t move the needle on churn.

Sales overpromises? 
>>>>Customers will disengage when the product doesnâ€™t match expectations.

Product builds in a silo? 
>>>>CS canâ€™t deliver success without the right features and workflows.

CS isnâ€™t aligned? 
>>>>Activation slows, and customers struggle to realize value quickly.

Retention isnâ€™t a CS problemâ€”itâ€™s a Revenue Operations problem.

The fastest-growing SaaS startups operationalize the relationship between Sales, Product, and CS to drive sustainable revenue growth. If youâ€™re seeing churn, slow expansion, or low activation, the first step is mapping out where these teams AREN'T aligned.

ðŸ‘‰ Are these teams working together in your org, or just working NEAR each other?
--
#SaaS #retention #revenueoperations #founders #customersuccess #product #sales #growth #alignment

poster.headline: ðŸ“ˆ Fractional Ops + Customer Journey | Startup Consultant | Tech Equity

linkedin_data.text: AI-powered customer health scoring can identify churn risks early, personalize engagement, and drive stronger retention. But not every startup is ready for tools like Gainsight, ChurnZero, or Totango.

Every SaaS company faces growing pains, but knowing which stage you're in helps you make the right decisions before churn, inefficiencies, or stalled expansion slow you down.

Are new customers activating fast enough, or are we losing them before they see value? 
>> Pre-Revenue / Early-Stage SaaS: Focus on ICP, onboarding, and early retention.

Is our revenue growth predictable, or are churn and expansion struggles creating instability? 
>> Post-Revenue / Scaling: Prioritize customer success operations, NRR, and upsell strategies.

Do we have the right systems in place to scale efficiently, or is growth exposing operational weaknesses? 
>> Growth-Stage SaaS: Optimize RevOps, automation, and customer insights.

Weâ€™re excited to announce the promotion of Reshma Dhawan to Lead Job Coach.

Meet Reshma: Her journey to auticon began when she had a passion for Community Based Instruction and how it could lead to better career outcomes for adults on the autism spectrum. Her curiosity led her to become a Job Coach at auticon in 2020, after a long career as a special education teacher. Today, she works with our clients, autistic consulting teams, and technology managers to better support one another and achieve our goals.

In her new role, Reshma will be leading her Job Coaching team with an emphasis on new training and professional development opportunities. Additionally, sheâ€™ll collaborate with auticonâ€™s global coaching teams to share best practices and new support services. 

â€œThe Job Coach position acts kind of as a bridge between everyone. Being a Job Coach has been the best job title that I have ever held,â€ Reshma said. 

Catch Reshma on stage at the 2022 TASH Conference in December, hosted by TASH: Equity, Opportunity, and Inclusion for People with Disabilities Since 1975.

poster.headline: Software Engineer

linkedin_data.text:
Recently I join to software development job interviews and common problem I saw with the interviewers that they usually ask knowledge questions rather than testing my learning skills. Most of the time I'm able to reply their questions but sometimes the question is about a very niche detail that I would easily solve by a small research and sometimes they just pronounce something I already know differently and we can't properly communicate. 

In my latest interview with Turkish Airlines, interviewer asked me about "event loops" in Javascript and I never heard this name before; but then when I research I found that this is what I've been already using for 12 years of my career ðŸ˜‚ 

I would suggest all interviewers to minimize knowledge questions and try to test flexibility and eagerness of learning skills instead, especially for senior level developers. Let people use the internet during the interview for example, observe if they can solve your problem. You'll need a challenging problem of course to make it worth for researching.

#interview #talent #softwaredevelopment

poster.headline: Information Technology | Cybersecurity | Artificial Intelligence

linkedin_data.text:
I have been navigating this job market trying to find a Junior Developer position and let me tell ya, it has not been easy. This whole process has made me take a step back and wonder what's really going on in the tech industry. 

I think we are in the infancy of a technological revolution. I am applying for all of these Jr Dev positions while also paying close attention to what is happening in the world of AI and I am coming to a stark realization lately. So here's my hot take on the situation:

I believe that if you are in the same position as me (looking for your foot in the door as a Junior Dev), you should make learning AI and getting good at using it/building with it a priority. Gone are the days of chiseling out code line by line into an IDE. With the multitude of cutting edge tools at our disposal, it's only a matter of time before the old paradigm of "Junior Developer" looks completely different. AI can write code better, faster, and more efficiently than probably 90% of the people in my network, and it just keeps getting better the more we use it. 

When I look out into the future and really consider where we are headed as a society, it becomes pretty apparent to me that I am watching the job I am trying to get slowly die right before my eyes. So I figure that it might be time to scan the horizon for the next opportunity. This is tech, if you want to stay afloat, you have to get good or you're going to get surpassed by the person who is good at the new thing. That's how it's always been. So I have come to ask myself, "Do you want to be the last of a dying breed or do you want to be at the very forefront of the cutting edge?" 

Just some food for thought. What do you think?

LinkedIn Profile Data.about:
Praveen is a serial innovator having founded several high profile startups--accolades include SharkTank San Francisco (Bay Angels sponsored) and the Plug and Play expo being voted most innovative startup in Silicon Valley by 140+ VCs.

He pioneered YouTube interactive, chatbots, shot the world's first VR zombie film, and won the 2015 AT&T mobile hackathon and is designing augmented reality stock trading tools.

He is developing VR/AR apps for Hollywood/Bollywood productions, professional sports teams, and newspapers. At 2015 eMerge Americas he made a virtual Miami Beach convention center tour and won the best demo booth award for StepFlix.com, the world's largest virtual dance studio he co-founded.

For the 2015 Facebook hackathon he made the world's first augmented reality social network/messaging app along with real time green screen augmented reality transparent video production techniques.

For the 2015 Microsoft IOT hackathon, he designed Star Trek Adventures, bringing Star Trek into your living room, winning two Hololenses. https://youtu.be/K3tAMZ3V4NY

For the 2015 Cedars-Sinai Techstars healthcare startup weekend won an award for PT/VR a virtual physical therapy/telemedicine app.

Previously, Praveen was a Founding Partner of Good Fortune Ventures investment team, Managing Director, India for Penfold Capital. Formerly at Dawson James Securities (top 25 investment bank in terms of deals completed), he was VP of Technology and Clean Technology.

In 2005, Mr. Yalamanchi was able to turn a $20k personal trading account into a $2M portfolio by inventing wisdom-of-crowds trading techniques.

Praveen holds two honors degrees in Finance and Computer Engineering.

Conjointly, Praveen is active among various financial, entrepreneurial, and civic associations including: TiE (Global Charter Member, Director of Sponsorships), Kappa Sigma Fraternity (Board of Directors), Network of Indian Professionals (President), Habitat for Humanity

Co-host Brennan M. Woodruff, Director of Strategic Partnerships at mHUB , reminded us of the need to understand the regulatory hurdles that have the ability to impact progress. (See BIPA). Alongside co-host Matthew Louis, thank you both for fostering a thoughtful space grounded in community, learning, and presence.

Elizabeth Barisik from Visier on agentic AI as a baseline for business and enterprise SaaS development â€” where data + context = the new moat. She emphasized the rapid growth of AI use behind the scenes, transforming ideas into tangible assets, way faster than we think.

LinkedIn Posts Data.text:
Nope, I'm not an agentic AI expert, but my understanding is growing every day! 

Great session today from the Agentic AI Conference hosted by Data Science Dojo. "Architecting Retrieval Systems for Agentic AI" brought forward a conversation where even a novice like me can follow along - with a couple of term searches :-)

Several takeaways about the future of agent networks:

MCP = Model Context Protocol. It connects AI models, like large language models (LLMs), to various external data sources and tools. Developed by Anthropic.
> MCP servers act like modular, authenticated data sources.
> MCP terminals can index a group of MCP servers, which can be chained together.
> Agents communicate across the created network using permissioned protocols.
> MCPs reduce siloing by enabling shared memory and interoperability.
> Real-world use cases: ETL automation, secure data retrieval, autonomous workflows.
> Integration with MCP is growing; Google announced adoption last month. This means that standardization is likely coming.

Deep expertise panel: Bob van Luijt, Raja Iqbal, Jerry Liu, Tallat M. Shafaat, Emil Eifrem

Much appreciation to 1871 for another impactful signature event! ScaleUp 2025 offered growth-stage founders the insights, tools, connections, and discussions needed to move into the next phase of maturity for greater scale. Special thanks to BMO Tower for hosting us in their beautiful space.

For those who missed it or are curious about the types of discussions held (and my quick take):

Keynote with 1871 CEO Betsy Ziegler and Alex Jones, CEO & Co-Founder Hallow.
Alex shared the challenges of scaling the #1 Christian meditation and prayer app while keeping his spiritual focus strong as a mechanism to push through growing pains.

Scaling the Future of Smart Farming with Oishii.
This is seriously cool food tech. Oishiiâ€™s â€œbeautiful tasteâ€ comes from perfect strawberries grown in a pesticide-free, climate-controlled, AI-enabled smart farming system. I can confirm they taste amazing :-)

Panel: Innovating Without Breaking the Bank, led by Stuart Bernstein.
In this economic landscape, this was the news founders need. Topics included enabling innovation, fostering a culture of problem-solving, and strategies for experimenting and iterating, all while staying aligned with growth plans.

Panel: The Future of Work & Investment, led by Angi Milano.
Lean scaling, organizational effectiveness, acceleration with AI as table stakes, the pros and cons of having a co-founder, and the evolution of investing through the VC lens.

Fireside chat with Betsy Z. and Wallace Harris, Jr., President at BMO Harris Investment Services.
The focus here was on building and investing in community as a mechanism for business growth and developmentâ€”a powerful reminder that community-driven growth is real. Wallace also spoke on moving past the 'no' to find workable solutions.

The 1871 team truly delivers excellence at every single event. Their behind-the-scenes efforts are what make these experiences not just successful, but impactful. Major kudos to the team!

Grateful for the community weâ€™re building. I got to catch up with Chrystal Price and Daniel Hernandez, and made new connections with Alex Olson and Mellini Monique.

LinkedIn Posts Data.text:
My father is an entrepreneur. Heâ€™s 75 years old. One of my first memories of his designs is a glow in the dark gym shoe sent to Nike in the early 80s. He never heard back.

Another one of his many memorable ideas was â€œBrother Aidsâ€ in the late 80s, to introduce adhesive bandages for brown-skinned people.

My mother was an entrepreneur. She sold Queenâ€™s Way clothing, Avon, Tupperware, Brown & Bigelow. I recall attending different home events.

In the late 80s they opened a t-shirt shop, selling a variety of heat-pressed and custom designs, plus my father was delivering custom spray painting designs. The business thrived. My sister worked there. My father began screen printing in the evenings, and they built to securing 1000+ item orders. I remember a lot of t-shirt folding!

My father later opened a cleaning business serving other businesses, employing family and friends.

My father worked full time as an electrician from 19 years old until retirement. He continued as a practicing electrician until his late 60s, including serving for several years as an electrician instructor.

My mother worked full time as a mental health physicianâ€™s assistant for many years. I would go to work with her sometimes, filing and calling the patients back to the doctor. Later she transitioned full time into the t-shirt business.

So, you can say that I was exposed early to building things from ideas as well as building dreams 'on the side'. 

Thatâ€™s why I favor startups, because I love the visionaries and doers who create tangible value at scale.

Cheers to those who have the nerve to build their dreams.

P.S. My father is finalizing a patent for a new product. Iâ€™ll be sure to share when heâ€™s ready.Â â™¥ï¸

LinkedIn Posts Data.text:
The Catch-22. The Gift and the Curse. The Rock and a Hard Place.

You really donâ€™t want your customers describing your B2B SaaS startup like this.

But it happens when... 
} The product is sticky but clunky.
} When switching feels painful, but staying isnâ€™t delivering value.
} When teams are â€œmanaging through it,â€ but not seeing outcomes.

Thatâ€™s not loyalty. Thatâ€™s resignation. And itâ€™s a churn risk waiting to materialize.

ðŸš« You donâ€™t want to be â€œtoo embedded to leaveâ€
âœ… You want to be â€œtoo valuable to loseâ€

So how do you avoid becoming the necessary evil in someoneâ€™s tech stack?

1ï¸âƒ£ Obsess over Time-to-Value (TTV)
2ï¸âƒ£ Align Product, Sales, and CS around customer outcomes
3ï¸âƒ£ Ask hard questions early: â€œWould you buy this again today?â€

Customer relationships built on perceived pain are brittle.

Value-first relationships are built to grow.

Where does your product sit today? Is it a necessary evil or essential solution?
#B2BSaaS #CustomerSuccess #Retention #Growth #SaaSLeadership #ProductStrategy #SaaSFounders

poster.headline: ðŸ“ˆ Fractional Ops + Customer Journey | Startup Consultant | Tech Equity

LinkedIn Posts Data.text:
Hereâ€™s the hard truth: growth doesnâ€™t happen until your product seamlessly solves real pain points for your ideal customers.

If thatâ€™s not happening yet, here are a few usual suspects:

(1) You built before deeply understanding your ICP. Always a no-no to build before the customer need can be articulated.

(2) You havenâ€™t talked to enough customers who match your ICP. Generic conversations with people willing to talk to you don't count.

(3) Your product solves only part of the problem. Perhaps itâ€™s too slow, buggy, or unclear. 

This is the moment to take a breath. Then take a step back.

You canâ€™t fake traction. But you can gain it with clarity.

Start by setting one simple goal:
>> Talk to 15 customers within your ICP within the next week.

Ask better questions. Listen for patterns. Revisit your assumptions.
>> Then: research, reflect, refine.

What might you learn, about your customers or your product, if you truly listened with nothing to prove? ðŸ¤”

Keith Toney, EVP, Discover: Talked candidly about AIâ€™s â€œchange ceilingâ€ â€” where layers of data access, organizational fear, and governance challenges can stall innovation. You have to recognize AI fear as real. Label it. Talk about it. Build the right sponsorship. And, only build things you can't buy.

Is your B2B SaaS startup ready for scale? Maybe.

Here are 5 signals that prove it isnâ€™t (and what to do ASAP):

1. No clear #ICP (Ideal Customer Profile).
 â†’ Fix it: Segment current users, identify your most successful customers, and build your messaging and roadmap around them.

2. #Growth is driven solely by new logos.
 â†’ Fix it: Build expansion paths into the product experience and train teams to spot growth triggers early.

3. Customers arenâ€™t reaching 'true' #activation.
 â†’ Fix it: Map the customer journey, define Time-to-Value (TTV), and simplify onboarding before acquiring more users.

4. Sales, Customer Success, and Product are misaligned.
 â†’ Fix it: Create shared success metrics across functions and establish regular cross-functional syncs.

5. Churn is treated as a customer support problem.
 â†’ Fix it: Build a proactive retention systemâ€”health scoring, feedback loops, and early renewal playbooks.

Scaling a SaaS company isnâ€™t easy, but it is doable.
The path forward is about growing smart. This means alignment across teams, clear operational strategy, and relentless focus on delivering measurable value.

Take some time to reflect. Are you building the set of systems to make your company sustainable?

I spend most of my time trying to operate in a balance of two states: (1) being objective and agnostic, moved only by evidence and data, and (2) relying on discernment, intuition, and energy sensing. The goal? To step away from judgment and make choices anchored in â€œWhat is the best decision for this moment?â€

This week, I caught up with a former customer I havenâ€™t worked with in years. To me, one of the best professional compliments is staying connected with someone as a friend long after the work has ended. Our collaboration was always about more than the contract, the upgrade, the support issue, or the delayed product delivery. 

At its core, it came down to transparency, honesty, owning mistakes, a sense of urgency, and a commitment to finding solutions. The same things we value in great people, not just great workers.

I recently read a book that described life as â€œone big referral.â€ It struck me as profoundly true, especially when paired with the idea that â€œpeople will never forget how you made them feel.â€ Weâ€™re sometimes led to believe that the smile, the laugh, the joke, the pleasantries > the humanness < arenâ€™t necessary for success. But my experience has shown me otherwise.

Do such good work, in such a great way, that people will carry your name into rooms youâ€™ve never entered. That theyâ€™ll think of you, not just for what you delivered, but for how you showed up. That long after the emails, meetings, and transactions fade, what remains is the trust, the connection, and the impact.

Because at the end of the day, the best work is both about what you do AND who you are while doing it.

At first, I focused on the customer-facing team aligning structures, goals, and processes. But over time, one truth became impossible to ignore:

Some of the biggest retention opportunities/challenges start long before CS has a chance to intervene.

Â >> Sales sets the promise.
Â >> Product delivers the promise.

When these three teams arenâ€™t in sync, even the best CS strategy wonâ€™t move the needle on churn.

Sales overpromises? 
>>>>Customers will disengage when the product doesnâ€™t match expectations.

Product builds in a silo? 
>>>>CS canâ€™t deliver success without the right features and workflows.

Retention isnâ€™t a CS problemâ€”itâ€™s a Revenue Operations problem.

The fastest-growing SaaS startups operationalize the relationship between Sales, Product, and CS to drive sustainable revenue growth. If youâ€™re seeing churn, slow expansion, or low activation, the first step is mapping out where these teams AREN'T aligned.

Every SaaS company faces growing pains, but knowing which stage you're in helps you make the right decisions before churn, inefficiencies, or stalled expansion slow you down.

Are new customers activating fast enough, or are we losing them before they see value? 
>> Pre-Revenue / Early-Stage SaaS: Focus on ICP, onboarding, and early retention.

Is our revenue growth predictable, or are churn and expansion struggles creating instability? 
>> Post-Revenue / Scaling: Prioritize customer success operations, NRR, and upsell strategies.

Do we have the right systems in place to scale efficiently, or is growth exposing operational weaknesses? 
>> Growth-Stage SaaS: Optimize RevOps, automation, and customer insights.

poster.headline: Software Engineer

LinkedIn Posts Data.text:
Recently I join to software development job interviews and common problem I saw with the interviewers that they usually ask knowledge questions rather than testing my learning skills. Most of the time I'm able to reply their questions but sometimes the question is about a very niche detail that I would easily solve by a small research and sometimes they just pronounce something I already know differently and we can't properly communicate. 

In my latest interview with Turkish Airlines, interviewer asked me about "event loops" in Javascript and I never heard this name before; but then when I research I found that this is what I've been already using for 12 years of my career ðŸ˜‚ 

I would suggest all interviewers to minimize knowledge questions and try to test flexibility and eagerness of learning skills instead, especially for senior level developers. Let people use the internet during the interview for example, observe if they can solve your problem. You'll need a challenging problem of course to make it worth for researching.

#interview #talent #softwaredevelopment

poster.headline: Information Technology | Cybersecurity | Artificial Intelligence

LinkedIn Posts Data.text:
I have been navigating this job market trying to find a Junior Developer position and let me tell ya, it has not been easy. This whole process has made me take a step back and wonder what's really going on in the tech industry. 

I think we are in the infancy of a technological revolution. I am applying for all of these Jr Dev positions while also paying close attention to what is happening in the world of AI and I am coming to a stark realization lately. So here's my hot take on the situation:

I believe that if you are in the same position as me (looking for your foot in the door as a Junior Dev), you should make learning AI and getting good at using it/building with it a priority. Gone are the days of chiseling out code line by line into an IDE. With the multitude of cutting edge tools at our disposal, it's only a matter of time before the old paradigm of "Junior Developer" looks completely different. AI can write code better, faster, and more efficiently than probably 90% of the people in my network, and it just keeps getting better the more we use it. 

When I look out into the future and really consider where we are headed as a society, it becomes pretty apparent to me that I am watching the job I am trying to get slowly die right before my eyes. So I figure that it might be time to scan the horizon for the next opportunity. This is tech, if you want to stay afloat, you have to get good or you're going to get surpassed by the person who is good at the new thing. That's how it's always been. So I have come to ask myself, "Do you want to be the last of a dying breed or do you want to be at the very forefront of the cutting edge?" 

Just some food for thought. What do you think?

http://www.linkedin.com/in/krystalrogersminter

Because AI integration in human life is moving at lightning speed, I knew I had to be in the room for The AI Collective: The Future of Work, to hear directly from leaders and practitioners about what theyâ€™re building, hiring for, and how AI is reshaping work as we know it. Co-host Brennan M. Woodruff, Director of Strategic Partnerships at mHUB , reminded us of the need to understand the regulatory hurdles that have the ability to impact progress. (See BIPA). Alongside co-host Matthew Louis, thank you both for fostering a thoughtful space grounded in community, learning, and presence. A few insights: Elizabeth Barisik from Visier on agentic AI as a baseline for business and enterprise SaaS development â€” where data + context = the new moat. She emphasized the rapid growth of AI use behind the scenes, transforming ideas into tangible assets, way faster than we think. Nickhil Tekwani- leading in product and Gen AI at McDonalds, shared how AI can drive customer feel-good moments through latency unlocks and improved experience connectivity. Nate Carson shared insights on Uberâ€™s AI adoption through the future of â€œhumanâ€ work in enhancing AI models. Chris Andersonâ€™s story was truly inspiring. I love how he and his wife brought their children along their science and technology journey. What started with Lego kits contributed to an AI-powered global defense system! Â He also invited us to demo his new product -Â Ai.rplane Makunde G. - building an amazing career and shared his journey to Google. He recommendedÂ book Algorithms of Oppression â€” a powerful reminder that algorithms can marginalize as easily as they can innovate. Makunde emphasizes community as the foundation for innovation for all. Michelangelo D'Agostino (Grainger) noted the need for net-new assets vs. retrofitting existing systems. He shared Graingerâ€™s rich Chicago history and how it has led in innovation over the past nearly 100 years. Cait Moran emphasized the humanâ€™s role in the future of AI, focused on emotionally intelligent design for autonomous digital teams. â€œDonâ€™t teach tools. Teach decision-making.â€ But my absolute favorite moment? ðŸ§  Following the event, a deep, perspective-shifting conversation with Shawn HE YUXUN on quantum AI and the future of human utility when our â€œfirst-person viewâ€ begins to orbit around AI. And the icing on the cake? I got to share the experience with my wonderful sister Kymberley R. â¤ï¸

Nope, I'm not an agentic AI expert, but my understanding is growing every day! Great session today from the Agentic AI Conference hosted by Data Science Dojo. "Architecting Retrieval Systems for Agentic AI" brought forward a conversation where even a novice like me can follow along - with a couple of term searches :-) Several takeaways about the future of agent networks: MCP = Model Context Protocol. It connects AI models, like large language models (LLMs), to various external data sources and tools. Developed by Anthropic. > MCP servers act like modular, authenticated data sources. > MCP terminals can index a group of MCP servers, which can be chained together. > Agents communicate across the created network using permissioned protocols. > MCPs reduce siloing by enabling shared memory and interoperability. > Real-world use cases: ETL automation, secure data retrieval, autonomous workflows. > Integration with MCP is growing; Google announced adoption last month. This means that standardization is likely coming. Deep expertise panel: Bob van Luijt, Raja Iqbal, Jerry Liu, Tallat M. Shafaat, Emil Eifrem

My father is an entrepreneur. Heâ€™s 75 years old. One of my first memories of his designs is a glow in the dark gym shoe sent to Nike in the early 80s. He never heard back. Another one of his many memorable ideas was â€œBrother Aidsâ€ in the late 80s, to introduce adhesive bandages for brown-skinned people. My mother was an entrepreneur. She sold Queenâ€™s Way clothing, Avon, Tupperware, Brown & Bigelow. I recall attending different home events. In the late 80s they opened a t-shirt shop, selling a variety of heat-pressed and custom designs, plus my father was delivering custom spray painting designs. The business thrived. My sister worked there. My father began screen printing in the evenings, and they built to securing 1000+ item orders. I remember a lot of t-shirt folding! My father later opened a cleaning business serving other businesses, employing family and friends. My father worked full time as an electrician from 19 years old until retirement. He continued as a practicing electrician until his late 60s, including serving for several years as an electrician instructor. My mother worked full time as a mental health physicianâ€™s assistant for many years. I would go to work with her sometimes, filing and calling the patients back to the doctor. Later she transitioned full time into the t-shirt business. So, you can say that I was exposed early to building things from ideas as well as building dreams 'on the side'. Thatâ€™s why I favor startups, because I love the visionaries and doers who create tangible value at scale. Cheers to those who have the nerve to build their dreams. P.S. If cancellations keep happening, the real question is what early signals did we miss? __ https://lnkd.in/gjZc9t67 __ #RevenueOps #Retention #B2BSaaS #ScalingSmart #ChurnReduction #KeepYourCustomers #Founders #VCSaaS

Every SaaS company faces growing pains, but knowing which stage you're in helps you make the right decisions before churn, inefficiencies, or stalled expansion slow you down. Are new customers activating fast enough, or are we losing them before they see value? >> Pre-Revenue / Early-Stage SaaS: Focus on ICP, onboarding, and early retention. Is our revenue growth predictable, or are churn and expansion struggles creating instability? >> Post-Revenue / Scaling: Prioritize customer success operations, NRR, and upsell strategies. Do we have the right systems in place to scale efficiently, or is growth exposing operational weaknesses? >> Growth-Stage SaaS: Optimize RevOps, automation, and customer insights.

Most of the time I'm able to reply their questions but sometimes the question is about a very niche detail that I would easily solve by a small research and sometimes they just pronounce something I already know differently and we can't properly communicate. In my latest interview with Turkish Airlines, interviewer asked me about "event loops" in Javascript and I never heard this name before; but then when I research I found that this is what I've been already using for 12 years of my career ðŸ˜‚ I would suggest all interviewers to minimize knowledge questions and try to test flexibility and eagerness of learning skills instead, especially for senior level developers. Let people use the internet during the interview for example, observe if they can solve your problem. You'll need a challenging problem of course to make it worth for researching. #interview #talent #softwaredevelopment

I have been navigating this job market trying to find a Junior Developer position and let me tell ya, it has not been easy. This whole process has made me take a step back and wonder what's really going on in the tech industry. I think we are in the infancy of a technological revolution. I am applying for all of these Jr Dev positions while also paying close attention to what is happening in the world of AI and I am coming to a stark realization lately. So here's my hot take on the situation: I believe that if you are in the same position as me (looking for your foot in the door as a Junior Dev), you should make learning AI and getting good at using it/building with it a priority. Gone are the days of chiseling out code line by line into an IDE. With the multitude of cutting edge tools at our disposal, it's only a matter of time before the old paradigm of "Junior Developer" looks completely different. AI can write code better, faster, and more efficiently than probably 90% of the people in my network, and it just keeps getting better the more we use it. When I look out into the future and really consider where we are headed as a society, it becomes pretty apparent to me that I am watching the job I am trying to get slowly die right before my eyes. So I figure that it might be time to scan the horizon for the next opportunity. This is tech, if you want to stay afloat, you have to get good or you're going to get surpassed by the person who is good at the new thing. That's how it's always been. So I have come to ask myself, "Do you want to be the last of a dying breed or do you want to be at the very forefront of the cutting edge?" Just some food for thought. What do you think?

Sencha, Inc. is a software company specializing in frameworks and tools for developing cross-platform web and mobile applications using HTML5 and web standards. Founded in 2007, the company offers a suite of products designed to streamline the design, development, and testing of data-intensive applications. Notably, more than 2,000,000 developers worldwideâ€”representing over 150,000 companiesâ€”utilize Sencha's products to build applications. ([leadiq.com](https://leadiq.com/c/sencha-inc/5a1d89102400002400629865?utm_source=openai))

**Key Products:**

- **Sencha Ext JS:** A comprehensive JavaScript framework for creating data-rich, cross-platform web and mobile applications with over 140 pre-built UI components.

- **Sencha GXT:** A Java framework for building feature-rich HTML5 applications using Java and GWT, offering adaptive layouts and optimized cross-platform HTML5 code.

- **Sencha Test:** A cross-platform testing tool for creating tests, managing defects, and storing results, with over 200 enhancements and bug fixes.

- **Sencha Architect:** A visual app builder that allows developers to build Ext JS applications using drag-and-drop features, reducing manual coding time.

- **Sencha Themer:** A tool for creating custom themes for Ext JS applications, helping to accelerate the design process.

- **Sencha Cmd:** A productivity and performance optimization tool for Ext JS applications, supporting the latest Java and Node versions. ([crunchbase.com](https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/sencha?utm_source=openai))

**Company Overview:**

- **Headquarters:** Austin, Texas, United States. ([pitchbook.com](https://pitchbook.com/profiles/company/43113-70?utm_source=openai))

- **Founded:** 2007. ([pitchbook.com](https://pitchbook.com/profiles/company/43113-70?utm_source=openai))

- **Employees:** Approximately 40+ employees. ([compworth.com](https://compworth.com/company/sencha?utm_source=openai))

- **Annual Revenue:** Estimated at $5 million. ([compworth.com](https://compworth.com/company/sencha?utm_source=openai))

- **Total Funding:** Raised a total of $29 million over two funding rounds. ([datanyze.com](https://www.datanyze.com/companies/sencha/346037473?utm_source=openai))

**Acquisition:**

On August 25, 2017, Sencha was acquired by Idera, Inc., a company known for its portfolio of database, development, and testing tools. ([mergr.com](https://mergr.com/company/sencha?utm_source=openai))

**Recent Developments:**

- **September 25, 2024:** Sencha introduced two groundbreaking tools for developers: ReExt and Rapid Ext JS. ([crunchbase.com](https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/sencha?utm_source=openai))

- **May 11, 2023:** The company launched features and enhancements for the next three versions of the Ext JS framework for enterprise-grade web applications. ([leadiq.com](https://leadiq.com/c/sencha-inc/5a1d89102400002400629865?utm_source=openai))

**Employee Insights:**

According to Glassdoor reviews, Sencha has an employee rating of 3.3 out of 5 stars, based on 23 reviews. The ratings indicate that most employees have a good working experience at the company. ([glassdoor.com](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Sencha-Reviews-E335067.htm?utm_source=openai))

**Contact Information:**

- **Website:** [www.sencha.com](https://www.sencha.com)

- **Phone:** (800) 212-2802

- **Address:** 10801 North Mopac Expressway, Building 1, Suite 100, Austin, TX 78759, United States. ([pitchbook.com](https://pitchbook.com/profiles/company/43113-70?utm_source=openai))

Sencha continues to be a significant player in the web application development industry, providing robust tools and frameworks that empower developers to create high-performance, cross-platform applications.

KleerVue Consulting is a business consulting firm specializing in assisting early-stage, mission-driven B2B SaaS startups in building scalable, customer-centric operations. Their primary focus is on enhancing customer retention, optimizing onboarding processes, and reducing churn to ensure sustainable growth. ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/about?utm_source=openai))

**Leadership:**
The firm is led by Founder and CEO Krystal Rogers, who brings over 15 years of experience in project management, SaaS strategy, customer success, and operational scaling. Krystal has a proven track record in leading high-growth initiatives across various industries, including K-12 education, law enforcement technology, and mental health tech. She has successfully built and scaled customer operations from the ground up at multiple startups, contributing to two successful exits. ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/about?utm_source=openai))

**Services Offered:**
KleerVue Consulting provides a range of services tailored to the needs of early-stage SaaS companies:

- **Customer Operations Development:** Establishing foundational processes, systems, and structures to set organizations up for scalable success. ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/our-services?utm_source=openai))

- **Customer Retention Focus:** Collaborating with leadership teams to optimize customer operations, implement repeatable processes, and improve overall customer satisfaction. ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/our-services?utm_source=openai))

- **Cross-Team Alignment:** Mapping the customer journey to identify high-impact programs that align teams interacting directly with customers, ensuring a seamless customer experience. ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/our-services?utm_source=openai))

- **Custom Program Design and Development:** Developing strategic plans and co-creating impactful programs to support enterprise-level growth. ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/our-services?utm_source=openai))

**Approach:**
KleerVue Consulting employs a three-step approach to achieve business success:

1. **B2B SaaS Business Assessment:** Conducting a detailed business process review, including analysis of the SaaS model, ideal customer persona, competitive landscape, and existing team structure. ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/how-we-work?utm_source=openai))

2. **Internal Process and Customer Interaction Discovery:** Based on assessment findings, suggesting areas for improvement and developing a concrete 6-month roadmap aligned with company goals and customer-centric strategies. ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/how-we-work?utm_source=openai))

3. **Execute Playbook:** Implementing the developed playbook alongside the client's team, continuously monitoring data and results to ensure progress in the right direction. ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/how-we-work?utm_source=openai))

**Client Testimonial:**
An AI Tech Founder expressed appreciation for KleerVue Consulting's support, stating, "Thank you, KleerVue Consulting, for your hard work and dedication in supporting our growth! We wouldn't be where we are today without your excellent support!" ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/our-services?utm_source=openai))

**Contact Information:**
For more information or to schedule a consultation, KleerVue Consulting can be reached at info@kleervueconsulting.com. ([kleervueconsulting.com](https://kleervueconsulting.com/our-services?utm_source=openai))

By focusing on customer success and operational efficiency, KleerVue Consulting aims to help SaaS startups achieve rapid growth and long-term impact.

8020 Capital is a venture capital firm founded in 2022 by Osama Al-Salloum. The firm focuses on investing in and developing emerging technology-driven startups, particularly in Saudi Arabia and the United States. In May 2022, 8020 Capital launched a $10 million accelerator and startup studio fund aimed at supporting tech startups committed to contributing to the economy and enhancing business empowerment capabilities. The firm is a graduate of the Accelerator and Startup Studio program in Silicon Valley, San Francisco. ([wamda.com](https://www.wamda.com/2022/05/8020-capital-launches-10-million-accelerator-fund?utm_source=openai))

The accelerator fund targets founders based in Saudi Arabia and the U.S. who are dedicated to improving the quality of life globally. 8020 Capital leverages its network of over 9,000 founders and its track record of successful investments to support new founders in building companies with significant growth potential. ([wamda.com](https://www.wamda.com/2022/05/8020-capital-launches-10-million-accelerator-fund?utm_source=openai))

The firm's vision is to bridge the gap between emerging startups with real growth potential, a receptive consumer market, and investors seeking to diversify their portfolios. By guiding founders from the initial stages to securing larger-scale funding, 8020 Capital aims to foster the development of unicorn companies. ([wamda.com](https://www.wamda.com/2022/05/8020-capital-launches-10-million-accelerator-fund?utm_source=openai))

8020 Capital is headquartered in Dammam, Saudi Arabia. ([alienszone.com](https://alienszone.com/organizations/8020-capital?utm_source=openai))

Kids Care Finder is a Carlsbad, California-based company that offers a comprehensive online platform connecting families with a wide range of child-related services. Their website serves as a centralized resource for parents seeking childcare options, extracurricular activities, and various service providers for children from birth through adolescence.

**Services Offered:**

- **Childcare Providers:** Access to daycares, preschools, babysitters, nannies, and in-home daycare services.

- **Programs and Activities:** Information on swim lessons, music and dance classes, sports programs, summer camps, parent-and-me classes, special needs programs, and birthday party services.

- **Service Providers:** Listings for pediatricians, dentists, mental health professionals, drivers, and other child-focused services.

The platform is designed to simplify the search process by allowing families to filter providers based on specific needs, view ratings and reviews, and access detailed information on each provider. Additionally, it offers functionalities such as managing waitlists, submitting online applications, and completing enrollment documents electronically, thereby reducing administrative burdens for both families and service providers. ([carlsbad.org](https://carlsbad.org/how-kids-care-finder-can-help-ease-the-childcare-crisis-in-america/?utm_source=openai))

**Company Background:**

- **Founding and Leadership:** Kids Care Finder was established on September 6, 2022, by founder and CEO Olivia Rutman. The company is registered as a Limited Liability Company (LLC) in California. ([bizprofile.net](https://www.bizprofile.net/ca/carlsbad/kids-care-finder-llc?utm_source=openai))

- **Location:** The company's principal address is 6659 Encelia Place, Carlsbad, CA 92011. ([bizprofile.net](https://www.bizprofile.net/ca/carlsbad/kids-care-finder-llc?utm_source=openai))

- **Team Expansion:** In 2023, the company welcomed Todd Baur as Chief Technology Officer (CTO) and future Co-Founder. Baur brings experience from companies like Tesla and StubHub, as well as multiple startups. ([wefunder.com](https://wefunder.com/kidscarefinder?utm_source=openai))

**Funding and Growth:**

Kids Care Finder initiated a pre-seed funding round aiming to raise $1 million to support operations for the next 12-18 months. The funds are intended for engineering enhancements, expansion of care categories, new feature development, and the creation of an AI tool. The company has outlined a fundraising roadmap targeting profitability with each round, with plans for a potential exit within five years. ([wefunder.com](https://wefunder.com/kidscarefinder?utm_source=openai))

**Community Engagement:**

The company has been actively involved in the Carlsbad community, with the Carlsbad Chamber of Commerce congratulating Kids Care Finder on its official launch in July 2023. ([carlsbad.org](https://carlsbad.org/kids-care-finder-7-7-2023/?utm_source=openai))

**Trademark Application:**

On January 5, 2023, Kids Care Finder LLC filed a trademark application for the name "KIDS CARE FINDER," covering services related to advertising, marketing, and providing a website featuring ratings and reviews of childcare services. ([trademarks.justia.com](https://trademarks.justia.com/977/43/kids-care-97743124.html?utm_source=openai))

In summary, Kids Care Finder is a growing company dedicated to simplifying the process of finding and managing child-related services through its comprehensive online platform.

Maintaining Competitive Edge through Innovation Sencha operates in a highly competitive industry with constant advancements in web and mobile application development tools. Cross-Team Alignment Issues KleerVue Consulting emphasizes mapping the customer journey and aligning teams, indicating potential misalignment between sales, customer success, and product teams.
